metadata.Description: Island nations facing unique challenges related to sustainable development, climate change, and vulnerability to natural disasters.

entities.Description: Markets where electricity, natural gas, and other energy commodities are bought and sold.

Climate resilience funds are financial mechanisms that provide funding for projects and initiatives aimed at enhancing the resilience of communities, ecosystems, and infrastructure to climate change impacts.
Agencies that promote and support the development and use of renewable energy sources.
Strategies and actions taken to adapt to the impacts of climate change.
The use of less energy to provide the same level of output or service, resulting in reduced energy consumption, cost savings, and environmental benefits.
The process of capturing and storing energy for later use.
Organizations that focus on energy issues within a specific region.

relations.Description: Small island developing states employ renewable energy technologies to reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels and enhance energy self-sufficiency.
relations.Subject: small island developing states

relations.Description: Small island developing states collaborate with international organizations to access funding and technical expertise for sustainable energy projects.

relations.Subject: small island developing states

relations.Description: Small island developing states measure their renewable energy capacity to track progress towards their clean energy targets and identify areas for improvement.
relations.Subject: small island developing states

relations.Description: Small island developing states align their sustainable energy efforts with the Sustainable Development Goals to ensure a holistic and integrated approach to development.
relations.Subject: small island developing states

relations.Description: Small island developing states are an instance of vulnerable communities that are disproportionately affected by climate change and rely on sustainable energy solutions for resilience.
